column11: Review Text

column8: Kalpitiya tuk tuk service Call me if you are interested visit Dutch fort kalpitiya and village tour WhatsApp number+94751592032
column11: Kalpitiya Dutch Fort is an amazing place to visit the kalpitiya village Sri Lanka ending more tourists and local people visit
You can not get in. The navy will not allow it. What a waste for srilanka's tourism and what a waste of time... so sad

Beautiful, quaint little church. Well looked after and worth a visit if you are in Kalpitiya. The wooden structure still is in good condition even though the adjacent grounds could be better maintained.
This place is open 8am and close 4pm This place is take cared by Sri lankan Navy, so keeping this place properly No need to pay enter. Avoid mid day time as it is so hot 1 hour is enough for visiting
A small building with unique dutch architecture, dates back to the times when Sri Lanka was occupied by the Dutch.  Something of historical value
one of very heretical place dutch fort and dutch church in Kalpitiya. old memorial place. It build up in dutch period. close to the fish Haber.

Visiting the Dutch Fort of Kalpitiya exposed us to the Colonial history of Sri Lanka. Appreciated the support given by the Navy officers to make our visit valuable. However, make sure to bring caps or hats if you are visiting the fort in noon.

The fort is situated in the naval camp and a cadet provides a guided tour.  The fort is reasonably well kept but needs restoration and preservation. Worth a visit but nothing spectacular except if you are interested in history.

This place is a Navy Base now. You need to get the permission from the Navy officers to enter the fortress. It is not a cumbersome task. Then one Navy officer will come with you and explain the important parts of the fortress.

I recently visited the Dutch Fort in Kalpitya, which you can only go in with a guide from the Sri Lankan navy. It was a nice experience and we had a very friendly navy guy who explained during the tour about the history behind the fort. You need to make sure you have either your passport or some other ID, as they need this to hold while you go on the tour. The tour is short but worth the visit

The Entrance road is pretty small as sellers seen in middle of the road all Muslim community is living here .The place is managed by Navy and they provide a great service .They will guide you through all steps. Photos allowed here and it's really hot on sunny days .

My husband and i arrived to have a look around, a very surly young man took my passport and kept it during the visit ???? but did not even look at or keep my husbands at all ???? the fort is unreal and you can take photos we took heaps. The only problem is that the guy showing us around was in a mad rush and could not wait to get rid of us so it was at a frantic pace. Being a military base there are soldiers with guns around etc also. Well worth a visit to see this piece of history

Took a free tour of the fort. You need you passport but with lots of smiles and apologies the supervisor gave us the OK. The fort is still used by the navy/coast guards? so you need a pass. The hole walling tour takes about 15 - 20 minutes. Don't go out of your way to see it.

An addition to your history knowledge about Dutch colonization in Sri Lanka. The Fort was built by Dutch mainly to uplift trade in North West region of the country. The historical site is maintained by the Sri Lankan Navy. To visit the place you need to provide your Passport or NIC (for locals) to the entrance counter. No entrance fees apply. Navy will provide you a site guide while you are visiting the site. - They will not accept any tips. The fort is part of the Dutch colonization and you will be amazed at the secrete tunnels they have built inside the tunnel.
This very old Dutch fort is used by the Navy.They have special security checks and specific times to visit.Its better to drive around and have a look.

We visited by Tuk Tuk to have a look around this morning. When we arrived the Navy personnel asked for our passports, which we didn't have with us. (No one had advised us to take them.) We were then asked if we had a driving licence which we did happen to have with us, this was checked but they then said 'no, passport only.' All very friendly but disappointing. When we arrived back at our resort, they were surprised we had been asked for passports.

After a very long time 52 years I had the opportunity to visit this historical fort. It is well guarded and maintained by the Sri Lankan Navy. Fantastic tour around the fort with a navy personnel with wealth of knowledge about the place, the history and sorroundings. In my first visit I was a very young kid visited with my family. There was no Navy presence there then. With my experience it is maintained well for its age and kept well cleaned.

This fort is situated at the end of the city limits of Kalpitiya. Currently under the navy but anyone can visit and they provide a navy guide. Only the fort rampart and walls are remaining. it is said dutch took permission from King Rajasinha (King of Kandy at that time) to build a church instead they built a fort. inner walls are done to a shape of a church wall so outsiders can get it wrong as a church.  Fort has four bastions on each corner. In 1795 the fort was surrendered to the British.

This fort is under the navy and used by them and also maintained by them. A navy personal actually guides groups pf people through the short tour of this small fort. Was surprised by the number of Sri Lankans whos were waiting for the tour.

I was escorted by a very pleasant navy personnel, fed me with so much of information. It is so sad to see how this fort is neglected and left for destruction as the archeology dept has not done anything about it. even the Church is neglected. it's disappointing to see it like this. property is damaged.
Small fort - walked escorted by navy personnel - most informative - regretfully and understandably - photography within the confines are not permitted

As this is a navy base, photographing is not allowed due to security reasons and a navy personnel take each group on a guided tour. Our guide was very knowledgeable and pointed out all the interesting features as well as narrated the history. The Dutch asked the king permission to build a church and therefore the entrance was built like one but inside it was a fort with stores for arms and training areas for soldiers. Architecturally, it is an amazing work! A must see attraction.
I have visited the Fort about 4 years ago, but this time was better as the Sri Lankan Navy, who looks after the Fort area, now provides a guided tour which is very informative.
Not a visit for everyone but teenagers found it interesting enough. Lovely Sri Lankan Navy  staff did the free  guided  tour inside the Fort ...shame though couldn't take pics.
Its really informative. There is lots of things to add in young child's knowledge base. Navel officer gave us a good support by giving us explanations.

Although much smaller and less well-known than its big brother in Galle the Kalpitiya Fort is well worth visiting if you happen to be in the vicinity. We were pleasantly surprised that the public had hassle-free access to the premises, this being a functioning camp and base of the Sri Lankan Navy. We were however escorted throughout the visit by a uniformed sailor who also acted as our guide. We found him to be quite knowledgeable and patient. Certain areas of this 17th century fort, such as underground passages, are out of bounds for safety reasons. Photography is also not permitted.

The Fort built during the Dutch colonial times is today a naval sea port manned by Sri Lanka's navy and houses a strategic naval base.  Public access is permitted only to view the Fort which is in an archaeologically protected site.  The underground tunnel which connects with the nearby Dutch Reformed church which was meant to be an escape route if the Fort came under attack during the colonial times is not accessible.  Take care when walking within the permitted areas due to rubble and loose stones.
Situated at the end of the world inside a Navy Camp this old Dutch fort is interesting to visit. Many thanks to the autorities for giving us authorization for the visit and coming with us.

Almost a 400 years old fort built using corals. It is occupied by Sri Lanka Navy. So you must take a pass at the entrance and not allowed to take cameras inside as their camp sight is within the attraction. Sri Lanka Navy will provide a guide to show you the places. And you could plan this trip along with another primary trip like dolphin watching.
It’s a magnificent place to see.  Unfortunately it is occupied by the Sri Lanka Navy, and doesn’t allow free access or photography.

The Fort is now part of a Sri Lankan naval base. The gates are closed, but if you ask at the quartermaster - they can offer a tour. No photo's allowed. The Naval Officer who showed us around new the history and was quite knowledgable. A traditional bastion fort, with both some original features and some later Sri Lankan navy adds.

There is a Navy camp inside the Fort in Kalpitiya and hence you need to speak to the Navy team outside before entering this Fort. They provide a guide and do not allow photographs. The ruins itself are almost destroyed and very little to be seen but the story behind the Fort and the structure related by a very intelligent Navy officer was amazing and took us back in time. It is a 17th century Fort with wooden doors still standing.
Due to the fact that the fort is inside an Army Base, it is not very well kept nor a true tourist destination. Its a shame that it is so run down and obviously the historic information is missing

As someone who has seen a few Dutch Forts in Sri Lanka, this one is very small but very charming. It really needs help though to survive and I do hope that someone somewhere in this world will help save it.Occupied  by the armed forces during Sri Lanka's near 30 year Civil War it it is now open to the public. Our guide was a very charming young man form the Sri Lankan Navy. This could be a stunning example of 17th Century Dutch V.O.C  military architecture , The stone battlements, and buildings withing the Fort are lovely.The tunnel leading out of the Fort is closed- what a pity. Would love to see it again after some loving care - and some serious money= was spent on it.

Again, this is now merely a place of archelogical and historical interest, but worth a quick visit. The premises are now part of the Sri Lankan Navy and one needs permission from the office plus they provide their own Guide, but it is free entry at the present time.

Visited the fort when I went to meet a friend attached to the Navy Base which currently maitains the fort. Admired from a historical point of view, the fortress walls and guard rooms and the remnants of the buildings that would have been used as barracks to house the invading Dutch soldiers about 3 centuries ago. Some of the buildings are still used by the navy to house sailors and to store goods. Managed to walk around the encampment with a navy guide who was very helpful. A rare site was the entrance to an underground tunnel which would have been used as an escape route in the event of a siege in the olden days. Couldn't help wondering how an attack would have subdued the Dutch garrison which would have been in station couple of centuries ago with the amount of defensive measures built in to the fort. Excellent place for a military historian to study stratregies of war of a bygone era.
It probably used to be a nice fort when the Dutch lived here. Now it is covered with barbed wire because the SL army uses it for its purposes. However I saw the prettiest turquoise bird here :)

If you're looking for a historic place to visit around Kalpitiya, Puttalam this is the place. We need to take permission from Navy prior visit the place. It is the current navy base of Kalpitiya. SL Navy gave us a warm welcome and gave a tour of the fortress. And then they gave us a boat trip around the Kalpitiya area too. Don't forget this area is really hot. and not developed yet. So dont expect food cities and luxurious shops here.

This fort is now maintain by the sri Lanka navy and there is an officer who has studied about it and who gives a very good demonstration. History behind the fort is amazing. The architecture and the structures are wonderful. It is again a must visited place

The Fort is one hour away from Ilanthi Adiya, and the road was under repair in fits and starts. But it is motorable in a car. The Navy Base is within the Fort and I assume prior approval is required to visit. I called the base and spoke to a gentleman who was more than willing to show us around and even gave us refreshments! It is a small fort and is not in good shape. It was built in 1667 on the spot where the Portuguese had a stockade and a Jesuit chapel, now the chapel is in ruins. There are also remnants of a commander's house, barrack rooms, a prison and several go downs. We were shown 2 secret passages which lead to the exterior of the ramparts. A few meters outside the Fort is the Old Dutch Church which is not in use. The only objects within is a heavy stone fountain, a few inscribed gravestones inside the church and the old belfry.
